did.langmaterial: The material is in English and Bulgarian.
did.abstract: George Nicoloff was a priest active in the Macedonian/Bulgarian Orthodox Church in the Detroit area from 1936 to 1991, and was a lifelong supporter of the movement for freedom and independence in Macedonia. His papers include his own sermons and religious writings, as well as records, papers and correspondence from St. Clement and St. Paul, the parishes where he served, and the Bulgarian Orthodox Diocese of the United States and Canada.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The papers were donated to the library in 2005 by Mrs. Vera Nicoloff (Donor No. 8978). Additional materials have been received.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, George Nicoloff Papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: George Nicoloff was born in 1906 in Sofia, Bulgaria. He entered seminary at the age of 13, and graduated 10 years later from the Theological Faculty of the University of Sofia. In 1930 he began doctoral studies in theology and philosophy at the University of Vienna. George Nicoloff and Vera Buneva were married in 1935. Shortly thereafter he was ordained to the priesthood and was selected to serve at St. Clement of Ohrid Macedono-Bulgarian Church of Detroit, where he first celebrated the liturgy in January of 1936.

While in Bulgaria, Fr. Nicoloff was well-known for his active role in the Macedonian Freedom Movement. He wrote for several newspapers and translated the Gettysburg Address from German into Bulgarian, the language in which he had it published for the first time. After his immigration to the United States, he became a leader in the U.S.-based Macedonian Patriotic Organization.

For nearly a decade after his arrival, Fr. Nicoloff was the only Bulgarian Orthodox Priest in the United States. He provided religious ministrations throughout the Midwest during this time period, and is estimated to have baptized, married, and buried thousands over the course of his career. Additionally, he served as a leader to the Macedonian/Bulgarian immigrant community, and helped many new immigrants establish their lives in this country. He was a frequent contributor to the Macedonian Tribune newspaper, as well as to the Voice of America radio broadcasts.

In 1970, the parish of St. Clement where Fr. Nicoloff served was moved to Dearborn Heights, where it became St. Paul Macedono-Bulgarian Orthodox Cathedral. In 1971, Fr. Nicoloff was elevated to Protopresbyter, the highest level attainable for a married priest in the Bulgarian Orthodox Church. He continued to serve actively at St. Paul until his retirement in 1991. Otets, as he was lovingly called by many, died in 1997 at the age of 90. In 2000, his family published a collection of remembrances of Fr. Nicoloff, a testament to the many lives he touched.

Please refer to the May, 15 1997 Special Edition of the Macedonian Tribune and the booklet In Remembrance of Father George in Box 1, which served as sources for this Biographical Note, for more detailed information on the life of Fr. Nicoloff.

scopecontent.p: The George Nicoloff papers document the activities of a Macedonian/Bulgarian religious and cultural community in the late 20th-century United States. The papers are divided into five series: Personal Papers, Planners, Correspondence, Parish Records (St. Clement Ohridsky, St. Paul Macedono-Bulgarian Orthodox Cathedral) and the Diocese series.

Most of the correspondence and many other documents in this collection are written in the Bulgarian Cyrillic alphabet, and so could not be assessed for content at the time of processing. Correspondence in Bulgarian is included either at the back of general correspondence folders, or, when it exists in sufficient quantity and can be separated from the main body of correspondence, in separate folders. Folders containing material principally in Bulgarian have been so noted.

Saint Paul Macedono-Bulgarian Orthodox Cathedral (Dearborn Heights, Mich.)

scopecontent.p: The Personal Papers series(1 linear foot) contains biographical information and records about Fr. Nicoloff, a few photographs, letters from church leaders, family correspondence, copies of religious items he wrote for the Voice of America and the Macedonian Tribune in the early 1980s, items published by the Macedonian Patriotic Organization of the U.S. and Canada, and records pertaining to the 30th and 50th anniversaries of Fr. Nicoloff's ordainment and marriage. It also contains information Fr. Nicoloff collected on immigration regulations, various Orthodox rites and customs, and the histories of the Macedonian/Bulgarian church and people.

Official congratulations from the Michigan Legislature
Biographical sketch written by grandson George Nicoloff
Miscellaneous legal papers regarding third parties 1924, 1941

scopecontent.p: The Planners series (1 linear foot) contains annual planners and calendars used predominantly for the recording of events such as funerals, marriages, and baptisms, along with some more conventional diary entries.

The Correspondence series (.4 linear feet) contains correspondence pertaining to Fr. Nicoloff's activities as priest at St. Paul Macedono-Bulgarian Orthodox Cathedral and Diocese-related correspondence, as well as a number of letters from parishioners.

The Parish Records series (.25 linear feet) contains newsletters, press clippings, photographs, documents pertaining to church committee meetings, and schedules of church events generated during the course of everyday Church business. Most of the records date from the time period between the move to Dearborn Heights in 1970 and Fr. Nicoloff's retirement in 1991.

did.unittitle: Photographs of church groups and activities, 1938-1950s
Programs from ground breaking, consecration and dedication, and mortgage burning celebrations 1969, 1971, 1975
Church committee meeting minutes and annual reports 1970-1989
Holy week activity schedules and flyers 1974-1988
Usher instructions and assignment list undated
Orders for candelos, cencer, bishop chair, etc. 1971

scopecontent.p: The Diocese series (.5 linear feet) contains records generated during the course of Fr. Nicoloff's work with the Bulgarian Diocese of the Orthodox Church in America. Many of the documents are related to the Diocesan annual conference, including Fr. Nicoloff's notes of the proceedings. Other documents include Diocesan publications, documents pertaining to local Orthodox organizations, and documents related to the split in the Bulgarian Orthodox Diocese in the United States in the 1960s.

did.unittitle: Split in the Bulgarian Orthodox Diocese
Informational publications and letters to parishioners 1963, 1965 undated
Meeting minutes and notes for Diocesan organizations
